summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, addressing the government's motion to require attorney David Markus to comply with Local Criminal Rule 23.1 regarding extrajudicial statements. The order finds Markus is sufficiently associated with the defense to be bound by the rule, despite his claim of not formally appearing, and warns all associated lawyers about the risks of public commentary.

events.title: Court Order on Attorney Conduct
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued an order requiring David Markus to comply with Local Criminal Rule 23.1 regarding public statements about the pending case.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court found attorney David Markus was 'associated' with Ghislaine Maxwell's defense and therefore bound by Local Criminal Rule 23.1, which restricts extrajudicial statements by lawyers involved in pending criminal litigation.

Markus argued he was not subject to the rule because he had not made a formal appearance in the district court, only handling appellate matters on bail, but the court rejected this as an easy circumvention.

The court highlighted Markus's specific actions: representing Maxwell on bail appeal, attending a proceeding, speaking to the press on her behalf, and authoring an op-ed describing himself as 'Maxwell's appellate counsel.'

The order serves as a warning to all lawyers, agents, and counsel for potential witnesses associated with the case to avoid public statements that could prejudice the trial or risk attorney discipline.
The government did not seek discipline for Markus's op-ed, and the court declined to rule on whether it violated the rule, focusing instead on clarifying the rule's application going forward.
